content: meeting in just under an hour
(Is this available for lurkers to attend?)
It's here on Zulip, so yes.
@T-release meeting!
first off, happy new year!
I'm going to skip wg-triage today - I believe we're still off this week
so let's jump into the 1.49 release "retro"
I would like to kick off with the blog post, which has been a struggle to pull off lately - usually arriving pretty last minute
Should we establish a draft deadline for that?
And probably share that responsibility more
I think it's been really hard to pull that off because any deadline other than the release is pretty arbitrary (and with open source etc there's unclear what not hitting it means in some sense)
At least, it would mean help is needed, and someone else could step in
I also think it is important that the post is written largely by one person over time, because that helps keep the language and tone consistent
I mean I think, at least a first draft deadline would be a good start. So that there's enough time for anything major to be added or removed.
I am not opposed to be clear to trying that, I guess maybe it would be useful to ask - what would we expect to do if there is not a post by that date?
I don't feel as concerned about tone, since these posts are mostly factual, not opinionated.

i think there's a few things going on here:

  1. december is like, the hardest time for me, generally.
  2. i didn't realize folks cared about the deadline this much
  3. honestly... the more this becomes a collaborative process, the less i am psyched to do it. that's not to say i don't like you all, or your feedback, or that things have been bad. it's just that to me, writing is kind of an art.
(Reassign?)
and so it feels more like i am beholden to what others want, so i'm just doing busywork
maybe that means i just shouldn't do it anymore
@Steve Klabnik in general, is it still something you're excited to do yourself?
it's complicated
it is like... the last thing i have in the rust project that's mine
but, i have been struggling to do anything lately
lockdown, pandemic, etc
When I suggest sharing, that's to reduce the burden, not add to it
so, in one sense, i am very excited about it, but in another, i feel like my brain doesn't work these days
and so that's also the harder part about deadlines. my executive function is through the floor
I can certainly relate to that
Maybe a good question to ask is if there's others (or shared others, to some extent) who feel they have the bandwidth to help/take over (at least on a temporary basis)?
so, maybe the right call is that explicitly i should step away for 1.50
I also noted that @XAMPPRocky you have release notes up already, which I feel like is 1-1.5 weeks earlier than I usually expect them, which might help us get a longer review period on the post

Yeah, in terms of how long the relnotes takes and getting them out quicker, they take roughly 3â€“4 straight hours. I'm going to talk to my employer about seeing if I spend that time during the work week, which would mean that I could have it out later the day of release, or next day, depending on what's happening that given day and when the release is tagged and released on GitHub.
@XAMPPRocky one thing that could be helpful is that beta is cut the friday before the release
back!
so it's in some sense possible to do release notes for the "next" release the weekend before the release, if you wanted to
Yeah, I also saw that, I could also try having it ready even before the release. Though I'll have to do some rejigging on the tool, but that's not too much.
but - I guess a good question to ask - would someone be up for committing to writing the release post, by, say, jan 25th?
that would be a couple weeks out from release
I'm willing to try it out
I'd also be willing to act as a backup to @cuviper if turns out they don't have time.
ok - let's maybe aim to kick off a topic right after this meeting and try to get a list of topics we can agree on by the 15th (next meeting) - would that be helpful @cuviper ?
(zulip topic that is to discuss which things to include)
Sure, that works
and then depending on how things go this cycle, we can maybe try it for 1 more cycle, and then see if it's a smoother flow for us
thanks folks :heart:
ok - @triagebot end-topic for release blogpost

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.

ok, and is there anything else on release retro?

@triagebot end-topic

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
ok let's do @XAMPPRocky first :)
hm, times I wish for typing indicators :)

Well I just wanted to mention, that we had a lot of regressions to point that we considered skipping a release, and I thought we were careful about what we merged, during the time. So I'm wondering is there something we can do about that, or was just since it was bad timing with the holidays and all?
I think it's due to the release train delay
I think the majority of the regressions were down to one PR, and that landed a while back - I'm not sure there's any significant take away
the PR also fixed a bunch of problems, fwiw
(including iirc soundness bugs)

Right, I don't have opinions on the PR, just felt like we did try to plan in November to be careful, and it didn't go so well, but you're right in that there's probably not much to take away so we can move on.
I think more broadly we just aren't in a good place regression wise / policy wise here
i.e. we have no good way of deciding whether to delay or not or whatever for releases
but let's not try to figure that out now :)
if folks have thoughts though I'd love to chat
@rylev you had something as well?

Related to @XAMPPRocky's point above that I don't think was fully addressed:
The release was during a time when many were not at their normal availability. Is there anything that can be changed to the procedure to make sure that such releases run as smoothly as possible. Perhaps explicitly asking at the beginning of a release cycle if they next release is likely to fall in a time when more people will be out, and to come up with an explicit plan to mitigate the impact to the release.
hm
so I think it's sort of related policy wise - I guess for example, I might consider that we might want to just.. have the ability to not branch beta for a cycle or so
FWIW, I don't think we have any releases on a bad period like new years this year, just looking at my calendar of rust releases.
i.e., skip a release
I definitely think doing more explicit planning in the future as to who's "on call" in a loose sense for releases around weird dates would be good
(and perhaps more broadly)
where "on call" to be clear just means like "around with a day or so latency"
personally I think the 6-week cadence is really important for the image of rust as a stable language
And not just from our team
if we say "we had so many things land we're not sure we can make a stable release" that doesn't send a good message IMO
right, yes, this would be both compiler and release and maybe tools folks
The last three release dates this year are Sept 9th, Oct 21st, and Dec 2nd.

Joshua Nelson said:

if we say "we had so many things land we're not sure we can make a stable release" that doesn't send a good message IMO

that's not at all what we'd say though?
The goal is not get caught off guard. There should never be the situation of "unexpected work needs to happen for the end of this release, and everyone is not available to work on it"
I think saying "hey we're going to skip a release because it's on the 31st" is not going to make people think rust is not stable
ok, that makes sense. mostly I want to avoid a slippery slope where we start missing more and more releases
in any case, I think working out a specific list of people/roles who are "good to have around" is definitely a great idea
but if it's a one time thing for holidays that seems fine

I do think skipping a release will have a cascading effect though, both in terms of technical infra that's built up around the release dates, and the expectation from people. So it should be considered the last resort.
yes, agreed

I think it's a good idea to just ask at the beginning of each release, if there are any special circumstances that put more risk than normal on the release, and then you plan how to mitigate it. This doesn't really have anything to do with deciding whether to skip a release or not. That's another topic
ok- I'm going to try to work on a doc on roles that are necessary for smooth operation of releases, and I agree on mitigation planning being more important to do when we anticipate trouble
Ideally this is a way to help ensure you never get to the point of having to delay a release
we did try to anticipate this one, however ad hoc
yeah, just not too much action as a result (beyond checking either Pietro or I could run it
but we should have/ should do more
ok, @triagebot end-topic - unless there's something else on this

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
ok - @triagebot end-meeting ?

Does anyone have something to bring up?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if you're ready to end the meeting.
thanks all!
